column1: If Everyone Hates Meetings, Why Do We Have So Many of Them? (NSQ Ep. 72)
column3: Also: why do so many people feel lost in their 20s? The post If Everyone Hates Meetings, Why Do We Have So Many of Them? (NSQ Ep. 72) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Mathematician Sarah Hart on Why Numbers are Music to Our Ears (People I (Mostly) Admire, Ep. 49)
column3: Playing notes on her piano, she demonstrates for Steve why whole numbers sound pleasing, why octaves are mathematically imperfect, and how math underlies musical composition. Sarah, a professor at the University of London and Gresham College, also talks with Steve about the gender gap in mathematics and why being interested in everything can be a problem. The post Mathematician Sarah Hart on Why Numbers are Music to Our Ears (People I (Mostly) Admire, Ep. 49) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: The Mystery of the Man with Confusion and Back Pain (Freakonomics, M.D. Ep. 10)
column3: Hear diagnostician Gurpreet Dhaliwal try to solve the case of a patient who came to the emergency room with an unusual combination of symptoms. Plus, we discuss how difficult it is to separate the signal from the noise when treating patients, and how cognitive biases factor into doctors’ decision-making.The post The Mystery of the Man with Confusion and Back Pain (Freakonomics, M.D. Ep. 10) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: How Much Does Discrimination Hurt the Economy? (Ep. 480)
column3: Evidence from Nazi Germany and 1940’s America (and pretty much everywhere else) shows that discrimination is incredibly costly — to the victims, of course, but also the perpetrators. One modern solution is to invoke a diversity mandate. But new research shows that’s not necessarily the answer.The post How Much Does Discrimination Hurt the Economy? (Ep. 480) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Why Is Pig Milk the One Milk We Don’t Drink? (NSQ Ep. 71)
column3: Also: what’s a food you love that seems disgusting to everyone else?The post Why Is Pig Milk the One Milk We Don’t Drink? (NSQ Ep. 71) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Marc Davis Can’t Stop Watching Basketball — But He Doesn’t Care Who Wins (People I (Mostly) Admire Ep. 48)
column3: His childhood dream of playing in the N.B.A. led him to a career as a referee. Marc is one of the league’s top performers after over 20 seasons, but he still reviews every single one of his calls. He talks with Steve about being scrutinized by players, fans, and management; how much work — and data — go into being fair; and why he talks about race with his colleagues and his kids.The post Marc Davis Can’t Stop Watching Basketball — But He Doesn’t Care Who Wins (People I (Mostly) Admire Ep. 48)

column1: The Economist’s Guide to Parenting: 10 Years Later (Ep. 479)
column3: In one of the earliest Freakonomics Radio episodes (No. 39!), we asked a bunch of economists with young kids how they approached child-rearing. Now the kids are old enough to talk — and they have a lot to say. We hear about nature vs. nurture, capitalism vs. Marxism, and why you sometimes don’t tell your friends that your father is an economist.The post The Economist’s Guide to Parenting: 10 Years Later (Ep. 479) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: How Much Do Your Friends Affect Your Future? (NSQ Ep. 31 Replay)
column3: Also: which professions have the happiest people?The post How Much Do Your Friends Affect Your Future? (NSQ Ep. 31 Replay) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Ken Jennings on How a Midlife Crisis Led Him to Jeopardy! (People I (Mostly) Admire Ep. 4 Replay)
column3: It was only in his late twenties that America’s favorite brainiac began to seriously embrace his love of trivia. Jeopardy!’s newest host also holds the show’s “Greatest of All Time” title. Steve digs into how Ken trained for the show, what it means to have a geographic memory, and why we lie to our children.The post Ken Jennings on How a Midlife Crisis Led Him to Jeopardy! (People I (Mostly) Admire Ep. 4 Replay) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: How Can We Break Our Addiction to Contempt? (Ep. 478)
column3: Arthur Brooks is an economist who for 10 years ran the American Enterprise Institute, one of the most influential conservative think tanks in the world. He has come to believe there is only one weapon that can defeat our extreme political polarization: love. Is Brooks a fool for thinking this — and are you perhaps his kind of fool? The post How Can We Break Our Addiction to Contempt? (Ep. 478) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Is the U.S. Really Less Corrupt Than China? (Ep. 481)
column3: A new book by an unorthodox political scientist argues that the two rivals have more in common than we’d like to admit. It’s just that most American corruption is essentially legal.The post Is the U.S. Really Less Corrupt Than China? (Ep. 481) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Is It Okay to Engage in “Social Loafing”? (NSQ Ep. 73)
column3: Also: why is it so great to be part of a team, even when you lose?The post Is It Okay to Engage in “Social Loafing”? (NSQ Ep. 73) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Edward Miguel on Collecting Economic Data by Canoe and Correlating Conflict with Rainfall (People I (Mostly) Admire, Ep. 50)
column3: He’s a pioneer of using randomized control experiments in economics — studying the long-term benefits of a $1 health intervention in Africa. Steve asks Edward, a Berkeley professor, about Africa’s long-term economic prospects, and how a parking-ticket-scandal in New York City led to a major finding on corruption around the world.The post Edward Miguel on Collecting Economic Data by Canoe and Correlating Conflict with Rainfall (People I (Mostly) Admire, Ep. 50) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Is Venture Capital the Secret Sauce of the American Economy? (Ep. 482)
column3: The U.S. is home to seven of the world’s 10 biggest companies. How did that happen? The answer may come down to two little letters: V.C. Is venture capital good for society, or does it just help the rich get richer? Stephen Dubner invests the time to find out.The post Is Venture Capital the Secret Sauce of the American Economy? (Ep. 482) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Why Do So Many Donated Kidneys End Up In the Trash? (Freakonomics, M.D. Ep. 11)
column3: Every year, thousands of people in the U.S. die while they’re waiting for a new kidney, yet thousands of available organs get thrown away. Bapu talks to a kidney doctor and an economics Nobel laureate about why this happens and how the system could improve.The post Why Do So Many Donated Kidneys End Up In the Trash? (Freakonomics, M.D. Ep. 11) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Why Do So Many Donated Kidneys End Up in the Trash? (Freakonomics, M.D. Ep. 11)
column3: Every year, thousands of people in the U.S. die while they’re waiting for a new kidney, yet thousands of available organs get thrown away. Bapu talks to a kidney doctor and an economics Nobel laureate about why this happens and how the system could improve.The post Why Do So Many Donated Kidneys End Up in the Trash? column1: Does Reverse Psychology Really Work? (NSQ Ep. 74)
column3: Also: does knowing your family history affect your identity?The post Does Reverse Psychology Really Work? (NSQ Ep. 74) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Max Tegmark on Why Treating Humanity Like a Child Will Save Us All (People I (Mostly) Admire, Ep. 51)
column3: How likely is it that this conversation is happening in more than one universe? Should we worry more about Covid or about nuclear war? Is economics a form of “intellectual prostitution?” Steve discusses these questions, and more, with Max, an M.I.T cosmologist, physicist, and machine-learning expert — who was once almost an economist. He also tells Steve why we should be optimistic about the future of humanity (assuming we move Earth to a larger orbit before the sun evaporates our oceans).The p

column1: What’s Wrong With Shortcuts? (Ep. 483)
column3: You know the saying: “There are no shortcuts in life.” What if that saying is just wrong? In his new book Thinking Better: The Art of the Shortcut in Math and Life, the mathematician Marcus du Sautoy argues that shortcuts can be applied to practically anything: music, psychotherapy, even politics. Our latest installment of the Freakonomics Radio Book Club.The post What’s Wrong With Shortcuts? (Ep. 483) appeared first on Freakonomics.

column1: Where Do All the Bad Ideas Go? (Freakonomics, M.D. Ep. 12)
column3: Ideas are currency. This couldn't be more true in academia, where it's the job of researchers to think of questions and, hopefully, find answers. Bapu talks with economists Steve Levitt and Emily Oster about how they come up with ideas for studies, why most never make it off the ground, and what should be done with scrapped projects.The post Where Do All the Bad Ideas Go? (Freakonomics, M.D. Ep. 12) appeared first on Freakonomics.
